attributes.comment:
While I can see the reason why the USCIS wants to increase all the fees, I would
support this idea ONLY IF the service can promise it's customers a higher
customer satisfaction rate and treat the legal aliens with fairness and respect.
Even if the service can make such a promise, the proposed fees are outrageous,
especially for low and middle income families it will be a big financial burden. They
simply can?t afford it. Being a legal non-immigrant for the past 9 years and waiting
to get my green card, I am writing from my own personal experience.

Lately, especially after the Sep 11th, it is very obvious that lot of qualified, law-
abiding, hard-working individuals who came to this country get stuck in the long
waiting queue to get their green cards while other illegal immigrants cut in front of
the line. Not to mention at any given point, the way in which two different legal
aliens being treated is totally different; one could wait for years and years to get
his green card whereas the other one gets his green card in a few months.

The USCIS and all the government officials must understand the difference
between the ?illegal? aliens and the ?legal? aliens. It makes no sense to tackles
both parties? problems at the same time because each involves a different set of
complications, and it makes no sense to treat a legal alien like he/she is a
terrorist or potential threat to this county. By doing that USCIS forces a potential
permanent resident or U.S citizen return to their home country where his/her skills
which are highly in-demand are better utilized.

And also, USCIS has been so adamant in its position whenever customers or their
attorneys or their congressmen/senators contact them with a request to expedite
the processing on a long-pending application. The response we get is simply ?the
case is pending? or ?it is pending because of security review, but it can not be
expedited?. I personally received this kind of responses for more than 3 years no
matter who contacted the USCIS. It is very obvious that if someone was really a
terrorist or a potential threat to this country he/she might have already caused
some damage to this country. By keeping the application in a ?pending? state for
years and years, the USCIS is not going to gain anything, but only lose, i.e., lose
a well-qualified individual who could be contributing his skills and knowledge to the
U.S economy. Common sense says that why would anyone want to stay in this
country if USCIS tortures them. One more point I want to make here regarding the
rudeness/unfairness of USCIS is the recent announcement about rejecting
mandamus actions when a case is pending for an unusual time. It simple tells
that USCIS does not want to take responsibility for their mistakes.

I agree additional security measures must be implemented to protect this country
from further attacks. But there must be a balance between the security and
helping legal aliens.

Again, by improved customer satisfaction I mean that when a customer calls the 1-
800 no. the USCIS customer service representative who picks up the phone must
be in a position to actually help the customer, not just read the information from
the computer which is already available to the customer via the USCIS.gov
website.

To reiterate and conclude, I would support the idea of fee increase only if USCIS is
willing to treat the genuine customers with fairness and respect and also establish
a reasonable fee increase. Otherwise, if it continues to operate like it does today,
it may be able to raise all the funds it wants, but there may not be enough
customers to service.

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
